caption: Beautiful pet cemetery overlooking the Seine River. Touching and zen place, very well maintained. Small fee. Carry mosquitoe repellent with you.
Worth a visit but a little over priced when we visited. I don't like the idea of charging going into any cemetery to pay respects.
It's a wonderful place, people can pay tribute to their pets
The sweetest tribute to pets I‚Äôve ever seen.
Such a great place. Unusual Reaxing Magical
Unique experience and nice surrounding.
Touching and intriguing at the same time!
Beautiful view. .....
Super

The reception by the teller is as cold as a tombstone. 3.5 euros per person (in the end, what are the price of concessions and public taxes for?). You have to get cash from the ATM 10 minutes walk away. That said, the cemetery has its history and its character. An astonishing place, full of emotions, tenderness, intimacy and memory. It is surprising to note that many humans are not entitled to so much respect at their graves.

I came to visit this unusual place one weekend and I found it pleasant to visit with many different themes on tombs and a place of worship dedicated to animals. We feel the love and generosity towards the animals that the owners have towards them despite their disappearance. The only negative point is the reception which is very dark, you have the impression of being in the dark and the lady does not have a very great sense of welcome or not at all. We feel like we're bothering her. It's a shame.

High place of Asnier heritage. Unique in its kind, the dog cemetery mixes eras and styles, and is witness to numerous love stories between men and women and their furry companions. Take the time to wander between the small funerary monuments to spot the final resting place of some celebrities, or even some anecdotes about feline feats. The cemetery can be visited free of charge during heritage days.
I find this cemetery magnificent to visit. On the other hand, I thought that the reception was closed, there is no light at the counter and the counterwoman is cold as ice.
Unique place of its kind! A moving testimony of the affection of masters for their little life companions. Here the famous Rintintin and other pets of famous people were buried.

It's nice to see how the love for our animal friends doesn't end after their death... Many tombs are old and abandoned... others are very particular and cared for!!! The entrance fee is ‚Ç¨3.5 and they give you the map... only in French. The most famous one is Rin Tin Tin but also many others...
A timeless place... this cemetery for domestic animals... Full of proof of love by the owners. Very well placed at the water's edge.

A wonderful, quiet place just outside Paris. There are many beautiful graves here that give an idea of ‚Äã‚Äãhow much these dogs, cats and other animals are loved by their people even after death. The oldest graves are 120 years old!

Very touching place. The expressions of affection from pet owners are magnificent. The cemetery is not indicated and it is difficult to find it. The cemetery is also very poorly maintained...borderline abandoned... With the map given at the entrance it is difficult to locate the tombs. Damage... But I really appreciated the visit because I have a dog and these testimonies of love moved me. To see if you like animals

An unusual place but a real place to visit where you can truly appreciate the love that human beings have for their pets. Entry is not free (‚Ç¨3.50) but at least this incredible cemetery can be maintained. When the weather is nice it is even a magnificent walk. The first burial place of this type in the world, it therefore has its stars including the famous Rintintin and the Cocotte hen. The map given with the entry ticket is very useful and recalls the history of this cemetery very well.
All my dogs were buried there.

Fortunately this type of animal cemetery exists. Even if the price of the concession for the year is a price but it's nothing. I can ‚Äúvisit‚Äù where my baby who shared my life for almost 17 years rests. I couldn't have imagined saying goodbye to him any other way
A place to think about the friends who are no longer physically with us and we cannot forget.
I give 5 stars for this cemetery for animal quarters, it's not just the people we bury but our companions will rest in peace among all the animals that people have loved

for the curious and pet LOVERS, it is a place to discover without hesitation. you will find a tribute to our 4-legged friends. the entrance price is small, approximately between 2 euros 50 and 3 euros. the walk lasts approximately 1 hour. more if you decide to read each headstone.  there is the castle of asni√®res 5 min walk away to complete your visit.

Paid cemetery! 1.5e for under-12s and 3.5e for adults. And unfortunately the tombs are poorly maintained... a lot of moss covers them and makes it impossible to read what is written and to top it off there are rats wandering around, of course they are afraid and run away but not very pleasant üëé in short, disappointed with this visit.

I was here in 2007 and the dog cemetery was beautiful and well cared for. I am back in 2017 and I find a place dirty and most abandoned. Hey sad.  - I visited the cemetery in 2007 and it was very well maintained and very pretty, I returned there in 2017 and I found an almost abandoned place with almost zero maintenance: really sad for a place classified as a historic site.

Info: Small outdoor parking lot free for all, but always full (squatters, not visitors!!), it's a lottery to find an ‚Äúauthorized‚Äù free space. Otherwise, use public transport, get dropped off by car or park in town. In 1899, the author Georges Harmois and the feminist journalist Marguerite Durand, director of the newspaper La Fronde, founded the French Anonymous Society of the Cemetery for Dogs and Cats. This company acquired land on an island in the Seine, the √éle des Ravageurs. The cemetery then accommodates the remains of domestic animals, dogs, cats or birds but also other animals including horses or lions. Some have imposing vaults or monuments. It is written on the frontispiece of the building ‚ÄúCIMETIERE des CHIENS‚Äù and yet, there are also numerous cats there, the 2 species alone representing 95% of the tenants. Rental only of bare land, renewable, to which must be added the annual concession cost, burial costs and the masonry of the funerary monument. After a risk of closure in 1987, the Town Hall of Asni√®res-sur-Seine became the owner in 1989 and has managed it since 1997. There are officially 849 dealers from all over France and a few from abroad to pay a final tribute to their companion. 90,000 animals were buried here! On September 21, 2019, the cemetery's 120th anniversary was celebrated with the inauguration of the sculpture Alter Ego, created by Asni√©ro artist Arnaud Kasper, representing several animals. BARRY: Monument to the glory of this¬†Alpine spaniel, predecessor of the Saint Bernard, erected by the cemetery management. This dog born in 1800 and died in Bern in 1814 belonged to the canons of the Grand Saint Bernard hospice and is said to have saved the lives of 40 people. According to a legend, killed by the 41st, one night, a Napoleonic soldier lost in the middle of a storm when he saw him thought he recognized a wolf and in a panic killed him. In reality, Barry died at the age of 14 in Bern where he had lived his last two years. Stuffed body preserved and exhibited in Bern. RINTINTIN: movie dog of which one of the descendants, Rintintin IV, was the famous actor in the television series. MEMERE: a small stone dog extends its paw to a helmeted soldier. Born in 1914, she remained the mascot of the foot hunters for fifteen years. Monument in memory of police dogs. The 40,000th animal to be buried there was a stray dog ‚Äã‚Äãwho came to die at the cemetery gate in 1958. The cemetery management erected a monument to him. Thanks to numerous restoration works, the cemetery continues to receive dogs, cats, birds, rabbits, turtles, mice, hamsters, fish, horses, and even lion, monkey, gazelle, fennec, lemur, whose tombs are richly sculpted or simply flowers show the affection of their master. Living cats have their own domain, ‚Äúthe cat house‚Äù, maintained by an association which provides them with assistance.
A moving place dedicated to pets. Access is not very glamorous (Pont de Gennevilliers), but once there you will not regret the trip to this animal cemetery, the first created in the world (1900).

One of the rare animal cemeteries in the Paris region, opened in 1899 and located on the former island of pests (the arm of the Seine on the Asni√®res-sur-Seine side was filled in the 1970s), many animals are buried here including Rintintin . The site has a small car park in front and the Gabriel P√©ri metro station is 500 meters away, and the line 13 viaduct passes nearby.
The cemetery is beautiful and well maintained, a good proof of the owners for their animals to offer them a grave, however paying the entrance to see the graves is a little excessive I think.
Deplorable service, bordering on unpleasant. Impossible to park nearby and impossible to pay by credit card (because yes, access is chargeable for a cemetery).
Very beautiful cemetery. Always the money!!! .an entrance fee of 3.50 euros. guy

I have had a concession of 0.5 m2 for several years (it is the smallest that exists for a small dog), it costs me in 2018, ‚Ç¨148 for one year or ‚Ç¨4440 for 30 years taking per year, or ‚Ç¨3,114 per 10 years at the current rate), which is completely prohibitive (my parents' thirty-year concession in St Maur des Ditches costs me this year to renew: ‚Ç¨910!!!!).. look for the mistake .!! In fact the town of Asni√®res takes advantage of the monopoly situation of this cemetery for dogs (and cats) in Ile de France and charges the prices it wants!
A splendid site, a very professional and understanding team. Thanks to this corner of greenery, our animals who left too early can rest in peace in their little paradise.

So I find it abusive to pay 3.50 to visit a cemetery. What's more, I find the receptionist as austere as the place. Well, I didn't have any cash on me and it was not possible to pay by credit card. while we are in a period of covid and we constantly harp on contactless payment :)

Quiet place, wooded and very well maintained... A little expensive for my taste but hey you have to pay for the maintenance of the green spaces... The staff at the reception are smiling, warm and quick to answer all questions (rare these days)

A Haven of Peace for these Unique and Exceptional Companions! A Final Step for Those Who Will Always Love Them... A Huge Sincere Thank You for the People who come to maintain this Place ‚Äúrich‚Äù in Emotions and Memories!!! üíåüåπüíïüïä ‚Ä¶
A place that allows you to visit your most faithful companion. The P√®re Lachaise of pets. A place to see.
